Edited 12/16/2015:
We've had pretty great communication with the DEVS and community members using the Discussions forums as well as the in-game error reporting features. Several users have expressed issues with Transmitters not calibrating correctly or at all with the software.  If you have an RC Transmitter, there are a few guides already posted and several discussions with topics discussing how we've worked through some of those matters - but there are ultimately a LOT of cables and variances in how they're produces, and even more Transmitters that users have. If you're  having errors connected, post it and let's get you flying!  I personally have a Spektrum DX6, DX6i, Taranis Plus, and Turnigy 9x and all work well using a USB cable. The Spektrum devices took several calibration attempts, and then additional Sub-Trim manipulation, but work well after.

* * * * * * * *
All around - I am really excited to see how they progress with this game. The 3 current levels are already beautiful and the multiplayer is going to be very exciting. Two thumbs up! (Then back to the joysticks!)

Note: While this game does work decently with 360 or similar gaming controller, I do not recommend spending time to get used to it. Gaming joysticks are meant to center themselves when you release pressure. This is ideal for most game situations, but not with throttle. While I did use the 360 controller for the tutorial and first test level, and it was decent enough, once got my Spektrum transmitter connected to the game and calibrated - it was a night and day difference. Much easier flight, it was much more fun and it was much smoother feedback from the camera also as you won't be bobbing up and down.

This will be a must have for pilots that want the FPV experience without ruining their setups or going through tons of props in the early learning stages. Would also be great for teaching purposes.

I have Real Flight, Phoenix RC and FMS Flight Sim that I have been using all three for quite some time. For a game delving into the FPV realm digitally - my first impression after 45 minutes of play: This is going to be amazing!!

Really enjoying the game so far! I fly quads already but I'm trying to learn how to fly more aggressive racer quads. I'm using the Taranis controller. Quick note: the game doesn't take negative inputs from the taranis, so make a new model, modify the curves to only be 50, and offset by 50. This means your left roll, for example, is really at what is normally the centerpoint (0) and your right roll is what is normally full right (100). You'll have to do this for all channels. In the guides section there's pre-made model files.

Great game! I love its drone simulation. The DIY Drone Workshop is very interesting, although I'm not sure how it affects the actual drone performance! The controller calibration and setup is very to use.

This game supports the Steam Controller, you can either use the standard Gamepad template as-is, or you can bind the gyro to the Right joystick, which means pitch and roll can be controller by moving your Controller which is an awesome way to control a drone. Make sure to bind a button to enable Acro mode which is super fun!

The only downsides I can think of is the weird max height (60m or so?) which you cannot turn off or raise, and super small map boundaries - not actual map boundaries, but artificial ones, so even if it looks like you have a huge map, you can only fly in 10% of it or so. This makes no sense and hopefully will be fixed. Of course, there need to be some boundaries, but they can be natural, like some super high mountains or something, or just make at least 80% of the map accessible, instead of what seems to be 10%.

Also, a great feature would be wind simulation - it would be nice to get some practice flying against the wind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I’ve long been fascinated with flying. It’s been a passion ever since I was a child. One of my dreams was to be a pilot. Had it not been for my poor eye sight I’m certain that I would have had the drive and the ambition to have been a proud member of the Royal Australian Air Force. My father served in the army and I’ve always had a deep honor and appreciation of every member of our military regardless of what branch they have served. Unfortunately, it wasn’t to be and so I’ve had to find a way to enjoy my passion through other means. As the technology has improved drone flying has become an increasingly popular hobby. Of course the barrier to entry at a higher level is prohibitive to many because of the costs involved. This is where LuGus Studios have stepped in and made it accessible to anyone with a modern-ish PC that can run their game, Liftoff.

It did not take long at all for me to gain an appreciation that the LuGus is not only deeply passionate about their game but of the actual flying of drones. They are a Belgium-based company that prior to Liftoff had only ever released one other title onto Steam though they have made other titles for mobile devices. They released the positively received but criminally underplayed Runes of Brennos a title completely unrelated to the drone flying sim.

The developers have worked hand in hand with some of the most experienced professionals in the world of drone racing in order to deliver the most realistic experience possible to market. Making such a realistic simulation is a long and drawn out process and one in which they have yet to complete. This, I am assured, is what LuGus deems to be the most important aspect of their early access developmental cycle. The team continues to work on this arduous process in order to perfect it. The team wants to perfect the simulation aspect of the game before moving onto the implementation of other game play features. However, what is already featured within the game is sufficient to provide the player with an appreciation of just how dedicated the studio is to delivering a premium experience.

Something that I’ve found very impressive has been just how open with their community the development team have been. I have had contact with several people who have played the game and who are unrelated to the studio beyond playing the game. Each has had the same story when offering their thoughts on the game. The studio has taken on board their critique and constructive criticism and made an immediate – or very close to it – effort to improve the area of weakness discovered by the player. At no point has the studio been rude or abrasive. This will ultimately make the game more accessible and increase the potential player base. I have no doubt that while this will appeal most to drone experts that this will be a title that everyone will be able to take something away from.

Most impressive is the fact that the developers have put some of their focus into the various VR set ups that are being released later in the year. Furthermore, they’ve also implemented a system that will enable drone controllers to be utilized within the game. I can only imagine what the possibilities will be for the title when these systems are fully realized. The game is also fully playable with your standard controller. Due to the nature of the game you must have a controller at the very least. However, I am definitely considering the investment in a drone controller. It would definitely seem to be the best way to play the game.

Steamified looks forward to returning to Liftoff as advances throughout its development cycle.

This is me:
I've never flown a quad copter or any airborn RC vehicle in my life but recently took a strong interest in FPV quads. So after a bit of research I discovered this simulator and bought it to help me get used to the controls while I begin buying/putting-together my first quad.

As of 03/05/16:
(using Xbox 360 controller)

Summary:
I'm really enjoying this early-access simulator. It seems to be very well put together and is a realistic (within reason) FPV simulator.

The physics seem to be near spot-on compared to footage I've seen of FPV'ers, though I have to agree with some of the reviewers here, they do seem slightly floaty. The collision and prop damage models are good, but I found myself wishing for a less forgiving collision model when it came to tree branches. Perhaps there might be a 'difficulty setting' regarding the damage model in future?

The visuals are fantastic for a performance-oriented simulator. The models are well-made, and the film grain and distortion prove to be highly immersive and make me feel like I'm actually controlling (and crashing) the quad.

Sound design is passable, as is par in most realistic simulators in my experience. It would be nice to hear some improvements here but definitely not neccessary.

The UI is well laid out, though not free of small issues. I suspect they will be remedied swiftly and easily.

Conclusion:
I'm looking forward to multiplayer and any of the other features/improvements to come. I definitely plan on continuing to practice using this simulator for many days to come. Also, I'll update this review once I have a transmitter and have flown an actual quad so as to compare the physics.

Written/Updated as of 11/26/15 Update

WARNING: To play this game, you MUST have a game controller with the analog stick that supports range detection (Like a PS2/XBox controller) or a quad copter transmitter that can be connected to your computer.

Liftoff early-access is a simulator for flying a drone, or quad copter in one of the most fun ways, FPV (first person view).  Imagine being a little bird able to fly and swoop in and out of trees, buildings, underneath bridges, etc.  That is what this simulator and what FPV flying is all about.

Liftoff is early-access and is already worlds above every other simulator out there, and it's just barely getting started.  I get the feeling that this game will build a huge passionate community around it, taking all of our passion for the sport, and allowing us a digital medium to share the art of flying and to practice our skills when we can't fly (when our copters are broken or it's night time).  When it is finally release, if this dream is fully imagined, it will allow us to challenge one another to unique challenges unable to be done in reality such as fly in areas that are generally off-limits for FPVers (like in a big city, or an airport, or around an ancient mosque).

If you're interested in getting into flying a drone in first-person-view (FPV), definitely get this. First of all, this is really really hard. Darksouls is a cakewalk by comparison. This is impossibly hard for quite a long time and the tutorial doesn’t help. This game is clearly made by drone pilots, for drone pilots.

The games starts with the controls screen and you have to input what you want to use for what straight away. Not the most intuitive menus either. It then throws you into the main menu. Not as bad as the controls menu, makes sense. I thought the game might be hard so I started with the tutorial.

Sweet lord christ. Stupid tutorial. One of the worst I’ve ever played. Doesn’t tell you how to do anything, just what it wants you to achieve. Completely pointless.

After that, I tried to fight for what felt like most of my life before I could get the drone to kinda go in the direction I wanted it to go. I thought this would probably be good enough for the first race as it would probably be really easy. I was very wrong. The first race is astonishingly hard. And you have to do 3 laps without crashing. When I finally finished the course three times in a row (After enabling god mode in the gameplay options.) I was met with my three times and a total time. That’s all. I have no idea how well I did in that race. Probably really badly but that’s not the point. I then attempted an underground parking lot level that was ridiculous, quite honestly.

Regardless of all this, I’m going to recommend it because me sucking at the game does not mean it’s a bad game. However, this could be 100000000x better if the respawn times were WAY faster. Super-meat-boy fast. Really really fast.

So, overall, the music got on my ♥♥♥♥, the controls got on my ♥♥♥♥, the insane difficulty got on my ♥♥♥♥ but it’s still a good game already. That’s really saying something in today’s early access market where you pay the price of a full game to watch a peep show through a layer of ♥♥♥♥ just to see what the game might be like if the developers didn’t suck. These developers don’t suck, just so you know.
